column1: Please note that in this “Long” version of the Student Opportunity Bulletin, all
opportunities in each category are included.
For the list of only the New and Deadline Approaching opportunities in each category,
you may click & open the “Short” version of the Student Opportunity document you
(Download this entire PDF document in order to use the following links to jump to
This will be the final edition for the current school year, and a new series of Student
Opportunity Bulletins will begin in early September for 2025-2026.
At this point in time, options that may still be open are included in the various
opportunity categories below. Students who are still seeking summer opportunities
should apply ASAP to any options that match their interests and talents.
Keep in mind that it is always a good idea for students to ask for letters, certificates,
and other documentation of whichever summer (or school-year) programs & activities
they participate in. These can be kept in a folder (virtual or hard-copy) as a record of
their extra-curriculars, which can be quite helpful when applying to future
opportunities and for college admissions purposes.
Please note that in order to save space, many sections contain links to general lists
of related opportunities- such as for Stem programs, Community Service, College
Prep free programs, and more - be sure to click on any links that interest you.
2025-2026 School Year Programs: Please note that many sections contain programs
scheduled for the upcoming school year, so be sure to consider them and to apply
Please inform hblumm@stuy.edu of any internships, programs, community service, or
other summer activities you participate in – this helps us track and evaluate how to
best serve students in the future. We wish all our students and families the best as we
move forward into July & August – feel free to contact me with any questions or
Some highlighted items in this last edition for the school year:
EVENTS: The Columbia/Vagelos Medical Center’s STEMQUEST Day on
Saturday, 6/21 in upper Manhattan offers information on STEM programs and careers,
and is open to all students.
ACADEMICS: Yale University welcomes all students to join their “Science of Well-
Being for Teens” virtual asynchronous summer course.
And some free college-level College Now courses at various CUNY campuses around
the city are still accepting applications for both the summer & fall terms – check the
grade eligibility and deadlines via the links in this section.
MUSEUMS/ART: The Culture Pass allows all students with NYC library passes to
explore over 100 local museums and other city attractions – reserve this great resource
PARKS/NATURE: The Hudson River Park Science Leadership Program is a two-
month fall term program that teaches research topics in marine biology and other
STEM areas. It is open to rising 10th, 11th, and 12th graders and provides a $300
stipend upon completion of the program.
STEM: The Clear Direction STEM Mentoring Program is a free August to May
opportunity for current 9th, 10th, and 11th graders to attend career panels, college open
houses, tours of scientific laboratories, virtual reality centers, museums, tours of local
tech companies, and more in conjunction nwith STEM mentors.
And the Youth Space Program invites all students with an interest in aerospace to
submit research paper proposals, many of which will be referred to STEM experts
who can provide guidance & support in developing students’ research in this area.
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
Updated: The TomorrowToday Experience Directory: A new interactive resource
TomorrowToday is a digital companion to the weekly Student Opportunities Bulletin
empowers students to more easily explore, find, and engage with the many diverse
opportunities that are available in a more interactive way.
Students can access the directory via our weekly digital bulletin or at the link below.
Simply browse through the curated listings, find experiences that interest you, and
take the next steps to participate on the provider's website. The user-friendly interface
makes it easy to filter and search for specific opportunities.
We encourage all students to make the most of TomorrowToday's Experience
Directory. Dive in, explore, and discover your career journey:
New: Event Approaching: Columbia STEM QUEST Free Event
“STEM QUEST: Discover Your Future Career is a dynamic event to empower
students to explore careers in Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics
(STEM) and healthcare through themed workshops and panels.” Come and partipacte
in CUIMC Programs Fair and get some free giveaways and free snacks!
Location: Vagelos Education Center, 104 Haven Avenue, Manhattan
Application Deadline: ASAP: Registration Spots Limited
Ask Her Anything: An Honest Conversation About Women’s Health
“Join us for an afternoon of support, learning, and empowerment at the Center for the
Women of New York at Fort Totten. This special event is designed to create a safe
and welcoming space for women to ask anonymous questions about their mental and
physical health. We’re honored to welcome Nina Rondon of the National Alliance on
Mental Illness (NAMI) as our first guest speaker. Nina will address your questions on
mental health and share valuable insights and resources. Come as you are, bring your
questions, and leave with knowledge and support. Light refreshments will be served.
This event is co-sponsored by the Center for the Women of New York.”
Location: The Center for the Women of New York (207 Totten Ave, Bayside)
Event Approaching: Queens Public Library Intro to Podcasting for Teens
“Join us for a hands-on workshop where you'll dive into the world of storytelling
through sound. We'll explore fun warm-up games, brainstorm creative ideas and
themes, and learn the basics of recording and editing. Whether you're looking to
amplify your voice or simply try something new, this program will help you build
confidence and hone new creative skills in a supportive, collaborative environment.
Location: McGoldrick Library (155-06 Roosevelt Avenue Flushing)
“This 6 week program offers participants a chance to learn the mechanics of riding a
bike, the rules of the road, best practices for riding in a group and on the streets, and–
of course–the joy and freedom of biking. Meets weekly.”
Planet Fitness High School Summer Pass
“Starting June 1st, teens ages 14-19 can work out for FREE at Planet Fitness ALL
SUMMER LONG! But don't wait, pre-register now!”
“Pioneer Academics is a research institute for high-achieving high school students
seeking to conduct accredited research in STEM, social sciences, and humanities.
Come and join us to learn about this year summit theme: ‘‘To Lead is to Learn:
Cultivating Resilient Leaders for an Unpredictable World.”
Information Session Approaching: Columbia Summer College Edge Program
“In the College Edge program, students in grades 11–12 truly get the college
experience by earning college credit as they learn alongside Columbia’s undergrad
students on our Morningside campus. Students will also receive academic advisement
and professional development opportunities.” An information session will be held
Dates: July 7 - August 15; Information session on June 23
Cost: $2,574 per credit, with possible additional fees
New: Stonybrook University - Japanese Pop Culture: A Window into Society,
“Explore how anime, manga, and pop culture reveal Japan’s changing society,
identity, and values. No Japanese knowledge needed, just curiosity and a love for
powerful stories!” This course is asynchronous and offers 3 credits.
New: The Science of Well-Being for Teens Course @ Yale University
“This 6-week course aims to help adolescents by bringing together the best insights
from Dr. Laurie Santos’ popular Yale course “Psychology and the Good Life.” In this
course, you will explore what the field of psychology teaches us about how to be
happier, how to feel less stressed, and how to thrive in high school and beyond. The
lessons, along with short weekly ‘happiness homework’ assignments will prepare you
to put these scientific findings into practice. The ultimate goal is for you to feel better
Updated: Deadline Approachig: Cornell Summer Precollege Program
"Cornell University Summer Session offers regular Cornell courses taught by
outstanding university instructors. Enrollment is open to all—from undergrads to high
school students*, professionals, alumni, and any interested adult.” Courses include
Python for Non-Dyson Majors, Songs of the Summer: Social Histories of U.S.
Popular Music, Art as Experience: Sculpture, Fundamental Programming Concepts,
Principles of Design Computing, Fashion Design and Visual Thinking, Introduction to
Human Development, Body, Mind, and Health: Historical Perspectives for Future
College Edge Academic Year Program at Columbia
"Academically exceptional high school students can apply to take courses with
Columbia students and earn full college credit. Students receive access to the same
courses as Columbia students, an Ivy League achievement for their college transcript,
academic advising, professional development, and real-world experience at an Ivy
Eligible: Current juniors and seniors with a minimum GPA of 3.3
Cost: $2,810 per session (no financial aid available)
Updated: College Now Summer & Fall Programs & Courses
The CUNY College Now Program at campuses throughout the city offers free
college-level science, math, & humanities classes to current juniors & seniors
(sophomores may be eligible for some programs depending on requirements). The
application deadlines and course times vary for each individual campus - students
should explore their options and apply ASAP. See the link below for more detailed
Location: 500 Grand Concourse, Bronx (in-person) or Virtual (asynchronous and
Examples of Courses Offered: Introduction to Criminal Justice Administration,
Fundamentals of Public Speaking, Introduction to Community Health, Introduction to
Digital Toolbox, General Psychology, Introduction to Sociology, Introduction to
Probability & Statistics, The African American Experience, Expository Writing,
Examples of Courses Offered: Developing an Entrepreneurial Mindset, Introduction
to Cultural Anthropology, Speech Communication, Business Fundamentals,
Introductory Sociology, General Psychology, Personal Finance, Critical Health Issues
Examples of Courses Offered: Environmental Health Issues, Intro to
Entrepreneurship, Chem, English, Algebra and Trigonometry
Location: Virtual or in-person at 222-05, 56th Avenue Bayside, depending on the
Examples of Courses Offered: Organization and Delivery of Health Care,
Introduction to the American Criminal Justice System, English Composition, Theories
of the Good Life, American Government, Space and Astronomy Lab
5. Queensborough Community College – Robotics Summer Program
“Looking for something exciting to do this summer while earning free college
credits? Then the College Now Summer Robotics Program is for you! Students work
in teams in person on the QCC Campus to design, construct and program autonomous
mobile robots. Students will demonstrate what they have learned at a showcase on
Location: 2800 Victory Boulevard, Staten Island, NY, 10314
Examples of Courses Offered: Pre-Calculus, Psychology
Eligible: Rising Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors
Examples of Courses Offered: Classical Mythology, Programming for Everyone,
Calculus 1, Principles of Epidemiology, Expository Writing, Mathematics and
Everyday Life, Introduction to Media Studies, Basic Musicianship, Nutrition,
Introduction to Psychology, Introduction to Sociology, Introduction to Urban
Education: Topics and Issues around Diversity and Equity
For a full list of summer College Now programs at campuses around the city, check
For a list of Fall 2025 College Now programs at campuses around the city, check this
Many other colleges offer “pre-college” classes that high school students can take to
increase their knowledge of certain subjects, experience what college courses are like,
and, in some cases, earn college credits. Some offer financial aid. Here is a list of
Deadlines Approaching: And here is a brief list of some pre-college offerings with
Updated: STEP Summer STEM Programs: (Some Deadlines Approaching)
“STEP (Science and Technology Entry Program) Academy is a New York State
Education Department-funded pre-college program for middle and high school
students interested in pursuing careers in the STEM professions. The goal is to
increase the number of historically underrepresented and economically disadvantaged
students prepared to enter college, and improve their participation rate in mathematics,
science, technology, health-related fields, and the licensed professions
The program invites eligible students to participate in workshops and enrichment
courses in math, science, SAT, and college preparatory workshops. All eligible
students may apply, with different application deadlines for each campus.”
1. City Tech Bridging the Gap (BTG)/ STEP Program
This is a program that aims to increase the number of underrepresented students in
STEM professions. Courses include Algebra II, Introduction to Virtual Reality (VR),
Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (AI), Introduction to Medical Field and Public
Health, and others. There will be FREE MetroCards, textbooks, school supplies, and
academic workshops. Submit a complete application
Eligible: GPA of 70+, with a good attendance record, and who who meet under-
“The Science and Technology Entry Program of NY State provides historically
underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students with pre-college
educational support. SUNY at Old Westbury has proudly hosted the STEP program
since 1996. STEP offers core subject instruction and enrichment, supervised research
training by a faculty member specialized in their field, college admissions prep,
standardized test preparation, scholarship opportunities, college credit courses, etc.”
Eligible: Economically disadvantaged or identify as underrepresented in the
STEM fields and licensed professions, have a GPA of 70 and above
For a list of some other free summer STEP programs at several campuses around the
Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History: History Classes
“This summer we are offering three AP prep courses led by Gilder Lehrman master
teachers. Each course consists of 6 one-hour-long classes held weekly via Zoom.”
The classes offered are APUSH, AP African American Studies, and AP US
“Spend your summer at the National History Academy’s Residential Summer
Program. Walk in the footsteps of leaders who helped define and shape the American
story, including presidents, civil rights leaders, and soldiers who fought for the birth
and survival of the nation. Each week at National History Academy will address a
major historical period and significant theme directly related to the AP History themes
students are learning in school. Through written assignments, oral presentations, and
first-hand activities, you will explore history in a way that is possible only in this rich
Eligible: Current freshmen, sophomores, and juniors
Cost: $9,995 (Partial and Full Need-Based Scholarships Available)
College Passport at University Settlement: Intro to Calculus
“The Intro to Calculus program aims to support students who either:
a) do not feel challenged enough in schools;
b) plan to study a Math-intensive major in colleges, such as science, engineering,
Studies, etc.), or business-related majors (Finance, Accounting, Marketing,
c) hope to study in advance to better prepare for their calculus classes in future.”
Dates: Tuesdays and Thursdays, July 10 - August 7
Location: East Side Community High School, 420 East 12 Street, Manhattan
Fusion Academy offers a variety of virtual summer programs in which students can
take courses in their areas of interest, receive tutoring and mentoring service, or
prepare for college. Courses cover all subjects, and one-week academic camps are also
Location: Virtual and in-person options available (One MetroTech Ctr., Brooklyn)
Harvard Student Agencies Weekend Junior Academies/Summer & Fall Terms
“The Academies @HOME offers weekend programs curated by Harvard faculty and
taught by undergraduates to help students explore a career path of their choosing:
business, business consulting, coding, pre-law, pre-med, or politics.”
Application Deadline: Rolling Basis (applications are due at least one week before
“Are you interested in studying defining moments in our history while relating those
moments to the important issues we face as a nation today? This summer, the National
History Academy (NHA) offers a four-week program focused on voting rights, the
Electoral College, and more. Participants will closely examine cases covering
different aspects of American democracy. Each case includes a decision point
followed by relevant background information that the original decision-maker would
Eligible: Rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors
For information about obtaining Working Papers at Stuyvesant, check this link:
During the summer, working papers may be obtained from any public high school
For a list of some business-related programs & opportunities, click on this link:
Updated: The Knowledge Society (TKS) Innovation Program
“TKS is a 10-month global innovation program for ambitious high school students. By
the end of the 10-month program, students will gain real-world work experience with
organizations such as Google, Meta, Airbnb, the United Nations, and Mastercard, be
future-ready with a good understanding of emerging technologies such as Artificial
Intelligence, develop a portfolio of projects that can be used to stand out in university
applications, internships, and more, and learn the mindsets, confidence, and problem-
solving abilities you'll need to be a leader. And, you will be mentored by industry
professionals, and have the chance to earn scholarships.”
Location: Virtual or In-Person at various locations
Cost: Varies by location (financial aid available)
New: Wharton Global High School Investment Competition
“The Wharton Global High School Investment Competition is a free, experiential
investment challenge for high school students (9th to 12th grade) and teachers.
Students work in teams of four to seven, guided by a teacher as their advisor, and have
access to an online stock market simulator. Together, they learn about strategy-
building, teamwork, communication, risk, diversification, company and industry
analysis, and many other aspects of investing.”
First Session Dates Approaching: Fordham University Finance Institute
This is a one-week program that introduces high school students to the finance
industry and to leading business companies & executives.
Location: Virtual or in-person options (441 E. Fordham Road, Bronx) available
Deadline Approaching: Mapt Content Development Internship
"We are actively seeking a group of 15-20 students for a three-week product
management internship. The selected students admitted into the program will become
Content Development Interns. This means they will collaborate with other lead
student interns to create a milestone worth of in-app content for the Mapt College
Planning mobile app. Interns will ultimately help Mapt’s product team to build a
Dates: July 14 – August 1 (2 or 3 times per week)
Program Dates Approaching: Exploring Entrepreneurship: One Week High
“During this week-long intensive, students will gain a comprehensive overview of the
entrepreneurial process in a hands-on fashion. From coming up with a business idea,
testing & refining, and ultimately pitching that idea to a panel of university professors
and entrepreneurs, this week will prove to be a thought-provoking, skills-building, and
Locations: Fordham Rose Hill, Bronx Campus & Lincoln Center, Manhattan Campus
The Career Opportunities in the Accounting Profession (COAP) Program
“The program provides real insight into how CPAs influence the business world. The
program is an important component of the New York State Society of CPAs'
(NYSSCPA) efforts to recruit minorities into the accounting profession. The Career
Opportunities in the Accounting Profession (COAP) program is open to all, regardless
of race, color, national origin, or sex.”
Eligible: All students ; under-represented groups encouraged to apply
Dates: June 23 – 24, July 7 – 8, July 7 – 10, July 9 – 10, July 14 – 16
Deadline Approaching: Young Women’s Institute Business Program (YWI)
“The Young Women’s Institute is a program run by the Kelley School of Business at
Indiana University in Bloomington, Indiana, that introduces young women to the
world of business through lectures, workshops, and practical endeavors. During the
one-day program, participants get to join workshops that feature top faculty members.
The YWI gives participants access to current business students and alumni, a chance
to explore a real-world business case project, build leadership and communication
skills, and connect with like-minded women interested in business.”
Eligible: Current sophomores and juniors who have a minimum 3.5 GPA
Location: Virtual and in-person options available; Indiana University (Bloomington,
Cost: Free (transportation and personal expenses not covered)
Career & College Readiness Programs at the Greenpoint YMCA
“All students may register for these free sessions, which teach career and college
admissions preparation skills and knowledge. They also offer free sports, recreational,
and leadership programs on Saturday evenings. And free SAT prep programs will
also be available later this spring. To learn more, contact Ms Brittney Russell at:
Dates: Wednesdays & Thursdays (3-6pm) during the spring term, next events on June
Contest Dates Approaching: Wharton Global Youth Comment & Win Contest
“The Wharton Global Youth Program Comment & Win is an annual contest that runs
from June to August and is designed to encourage high school-age students to
discover Global Youth stories, podcasts, and videos, learn about business, and develop
stronger reflective and persuasive commenting skills.
Four biweekly rounds of competition include a new theme introduced each round.
Students can choose to participate in one or two rounds, or all four. Four-round
competitors are entered into the running for a special Grand Prize.”
Dates: June 16 – July 4 (first round), July 7 – 25 (second round), July 28 - August 15
The New York City Department of Housing Develoment & Preservation Summer
“This summer, we’re looking for motivated, curious students to join our small but
mighty Communications team at HPD — the city agency responsible for affordable
housing. Our interns get to do meaningful work that supports real-world housing
policy and programs, while also building a strong foundation in public service
communications. The internship is designed as a well-rounded experience that
touches on all aspects of what we do — social media, press and storytelling,
public engagement, and event planning for senior leadership. Interns gain hands-
on experience drafting content, helping shape communications strategies, supporting
public events, and contributing to the narrative around how the City is tackling its
Interns will walk away with tangible portfolio work and writing samples, access to
professional development resources, networking opportunities with senior staff across
the agency and city government, and a deeper understanding of how large public
institutions work and how to navigate them.”
The New York Public Interest Research Group (NYPIRG) Climate Activists for
“NYPIRG, New York’s leading environmental organization, is hiring passionate,
motivated climate activists to work with our community outreach program in our
urgent fight against the climate crisis. NYPIRG is a nonpartisan, not-for-profit
organization that advances important public interest issues through sophisticated
grassroots organizing and advocacy, public education, and media exposure.
Our Community Outreach teams are building the grassroots movement to hold
elected leaders accountable, end fossil fuel dependency, and bring climate polluters to
justice! Staff will be paid $17.25 hourly and have health coverage and paid vacation
Hofstra University PreCollegiate Career Discovery Program
Hofstra University is offering various courses this summer. There are writing courses
for students interested in law & criminal justice or mechanical and automotive classes.
There is an Aviation Academy, along with a Veterinary Skills program. There is also a
program for students interested in the arts, in which they can develop their musical,
Eligible: Various depending on the program
“We are delighted to share with you our career opportunities, which are available in
19 cutting-edge industries. Learn directly from some of the world's best
professionals - doctors, lawyers, engineers, investment bankers and more - through a
series of live, interactive simulations which provide tailor-made professional
Available careers: Medicine, Engineering, Investment Banking, Law, Psychology,
Architecture, Art, Dentistry, Entrepreneurship, Fashion, Filmmaking, Forensic
Science, International Development, Journalism, Politics, Software Engineering, Vet,
Location: In-person in London (and other areas), or Virtual
“Through live, online classes your expert instructor will guide you to launch your
dream project, connect with peers nationwide, and gain the know-how to take charge
of your future. Build an entrepreneurial mindset and graduate with a business plan,
resume material, and the competitive edge to set you apart in anything you do.”
Eligible: All students identifying as women
Dates: 5 weeks starting July 7 or July 21
Columbia CORE Youth Entrepreneurship Program for High Schoolers
“Columbia's CORE Youth is a student-run initiative that seeks to empower students
into the startup world. We will cover how to develop an app, basic entrepreneurial
concepts, product design, and more! This is a semester-long program in which
students can join our speaker events, speak to founders, and go through a start-up
education program. At the end of the semester, we will bring all participants to
Columbia for a conference at which they can attend the Demo Day of CORE's
accelerator, and present their projects. Throughout the semester, there will be several
opportunities for networking as well. For more details, please sign up at the link below
“We are looking to hire graduating seniors for in-person tutoring positions across
various branches (we have locations in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and the Bronx).
Positions include Common Core instructors, SHSAT instructors, GPA/Regents
instructors, and SAT instructors. The pay varies per position. Workdays for instructors
are just on the weekend during the school year and leadership is understanding and
accommodating to college schedules and student life.”
“This free virtual program connects students who have an interest in business to
young professionals who help them with resumes, interview skills, personal finance
Dates: June - August (meetings twice a week, one weekday afterschool & one
World Series of Innovation Entrepreneurial Challenge
“Explore the innovation challenges offered this season and see what grabs your
interest. Set a timer and come up with as many ideas as you can in short order. Go
wild with the rapid ideation then look over your list and choose your best idea. Once
you've signed up to compete you can access the online entry form by clicking "Get
Started" and get to work building your entry. Just remember to submit your idea by
New: South Street Seaport Museum Volunteering
“Volunteers work to support every aspect of the Museum but are most often seen
working on the waterfront at Pier 16. Work includes cleaning and organizing, repairs,
painting, polishing, varnishing, and general maintenance. In the spring, the operational
vessels are fitted out and re-rigged for the coming season, and in the late fall they are
downrigged for winter. Most labor can be unskilled. Training is provided.”
Eligible: Students who are at least 16 years old
General List of Local Volunteer Opportunities:
For a list of some food programs that help hungry New Yorkers, click this link:
Program Start Date Approaching: DOROT’s Summer Teen Internships
“Help the Elderly Dorot” is a senior-services organization that runs 4-week summer
internship programs for teens to assist elderly New Yorkers in three separate programs
in Manhattan & Long Island. Over the course of the session, teen interns develop
leadership skills and build intergenerational connections through a variety of
Eligible: Current freshman, sophomore, and junior
Dates: June 23 – July 16 OR July 23 – August 14 OR July 28 – August 21 (Mondays
– Thursdays from 10 am – 4:30 pm or 5:00 pm)
Locations: DOROT 171 W 85th St, Manhattan OR at Suffolk Y JCC, 74 Hauppauge
Upcoming Museum of Mathematics Student Volunteer Opportunities
“High school students volunteering at MoMath can accrue hours for their school's
community service requirement.” MoMath is always looking for volunteers!
- Friday, June 27 through Monday, June 30 (shifts to be determined)
Seeking volunteers to help with inventory.
- Saturday, July 12, All Day! (shifts to be determined)
MoMath is pleased to present the Ninth Annual NYC Math Festival, providing a full day of math fun
in the sun for all ages
Seeking LOTS of volunteers to help with event setup, engaging with the public and the MoMath
exhibits, and the all-important breakdown and cleanup at the end of the event.
Location: Museum of Mathematics, 225 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan
Most NYC hospitals welcome high school student helpers. Age requirements and time
commitments vary, so contact locations of interest for more specific information.
“You're not just a part of your city, you're shaping its future. Now's your chance to get
involved, have fun, and make a difference! In partnership with NYC Public Schools,
we bring you hundreds of opportunities to engage in your community. Ready to join?
Register and sign up for a volunteer project near you.”
For a general list of programs (mostly free) that provide college admissions
information and support to seniors and students from other grades, check this link:
New: Harvey Mudd College’s Fall FAST Fly-In Program
“The Future Achievers in Science and Technology (FAST) is our all-expenses-paid
(in other words, free for you!) overnight fly-in program for high-achieving, college-
bound high school seniors who demonstrate strong potential to leave a meaningful
impact within the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics
(STEM). During the program, you will have an opportunity to interact with current
Harvey Mudd students, professors, and other high school seniors to envision a
Dates: September 14 - 16 (FAST Part I) & October 26 – 28 (FAST Part II)
Location: Harvey Mudd College, Claremont, California
New: University of Massachusetts/Amherst College Prep Workshops
“College prep workshops at UMass Amherst offer high school students an essential
toolkit for college preparedness: practical skills and knowledge to confidently
Choose from two invaluable online workshops: learn SAT & ACT test prep strategies,
or craft a true-to-life personal essay using techniques from UMass Amherst's award-
winning Writing Program. Or, join us on campus for a weeklong summer intensive
covering admissions strategy, essay writing, test prep and more.”
Location: Virtual or at 300 Massachusetts Ave, Amherst, Masachusetts
Deadline Approaching: Apex for Youth’s College Access Program (CAP)
“This program is open to all rising 11th grade students looking for individualized
guidance and support through the college application process and support preparing
for their future pathways. They will also have access to free college trips, paid
summer internships, scholarships, professional development workshops, and
community events through high school and beyond!”
Eligible: Rising Juniors (All may apply, priority given to those from low-income
backgrounds who identify as Asian, Asian-American, and/or from immigrant families)
Application Deadline: June 21 (Priority Deadline), Rolling Admissions (Afterward)
These in-person and online sessions provide helpful information about different State
University of New York (SUNY) campuses, financial aid, FAFSA completion, EOP
form completion, special programs, and more.
Dates: June 24, July 8, 22, August 5 and more
Location: Virtual and in-person (116 East 55 St, Manhattan) options available
College & Career Readiness Programs at the Greenpoint YMCA
“All students may register for these free sessions, which teach career and college
admissions preparation skills and knowledge. They also offer free sports, recreational,
and leadership programs on Saturday evenings. And free SAT prep programs will
also be available later this spring. To learn more, contact Ms Brittney Russell at:
Dates: Wednesdays & Thursdays (3-6pm) during the spring term, next events on June
“Students from across New York State will participate in a free, informative, fun day
program experience! Students will engage in small-group discussions, a mock college
course, and workshops on admissions and financial aid. They will learn college
interview and essay-writing techniques and gain leadership, teamwork, and
networking experience. Camp College is a great opportunity to learn about the many
post-secondary options in New York State and beyond. It is also a great way to meet
new friends and mentors who will support you on your path to success after high
Eligible: All students (priority to rising juniors and seniors)
Locations: SUNY Geneseo, Geneseo, New York
Cost: Free (transportation costs to and back NOT covered)
New: The Voice of Democracy Audio-Essay Contest
The Voice of Democracy is a democratic and patriotic-themed essay contest. This
year’s theme is “How Are You Showing Patriotism and Support for Our Country?”
Students will draft an essay that treats the theme with imagination and human interest,
record their reading of it to a CD/flash drive, and submit it to their local VFW post.
Yale Undergraduate Moot Court 2025 Summer Legal Scholars Program
“During our one week virtual program, you’ll master the principles of moot court and
put them into practice with our annual program showcase. You’ll be learning from the
best of the best — competitors on Yale Undergraduate Moot Court don’t just excel at
moot court at a national level, but are also involved in other public speaking activities
You will also have the chance to hear from legal professionals about their paths to law
school and to practice — many of whom did moot court in undergrad or in law school.
Through this program, students will develop critical thinking, legal analysis, and
public speaking skills, guided by experienced mentors and judges.”
FHAA Teen Leadership Program: Youth Ambassadors
“The Forest Hills Asian Association (FHAA), a community leader in advocacy,

“AAPI-LEAD is a 4-day youth conference that brings together NYC’s AAPI and
allied youth to discuss the experiences and issues most relevant to AAPI young
people. AAPI-LEAD aims to develop AAPI youth's understanding of and relationship

“The one-week Parrhesia Ambassador Program aims to introduce pre-college students

practice of public discourse and deliberation.

of argument construction and presentation preparation and delivery. Selected
participants will be tasked with serving as ambassadors and changemakers by sharing
the principles of discourse and freedom of expression in communities.”

architecture and urban design disciplines through a cross-disciplinary lens that studies

reshape our built environments and experiences. The program includes strategies to

New: Hudson River Park Science Leadership Program: Fall Term
“Selected interns will work in a team of high school peers and Hudson River Park
staff. Interns will conduct hands-on STEM research on the Hudson River, develop a
scientific communication and research project and present their work at the end of the
program at HRPK's annual Release of the Fishes event. Interns will attend workshops
led by local practitioners on professional development, science identity and the
diversity of pathways in the STEM field. SLP interns will develop proficiency in field
research, data collection and interpretation with the goal of strengthening
communication and leadership skills. High School interns will receive a stipend of
$300 which will be paid at the close of the internship.”
Location: Hudson River Park’s Pier 57 (25 11th Avenue)
Deadline Approaching: Rooted in the City Internship
“You’ll get your hands in the soil, learn to ID local plants and trees (yes, even the
ones growing through sidewalk cracks), and discover how fungi, dirt, and weeds have
medicinal purposes. Through different cultural stories and traditions, you’ll explore
how the plants we find in our city have been used for healing, ceremony, and
connection across generations. Along the way, you’ll deepen your knowledge of
traditional plant wisdom, express your learning through creative mediums, and start to
see the city—and yourself—differently. Together, we’ll weave our experiences into a
youth-led public event that blends nature, culture, and creativity: ‘Moving Through
our Senses with the Plant World.’” A stipend of up to $550 will be provided for this

This innovative off-Broadway theater company welcomes students (no experience
necessary) to join “A Westside Experiment,” their teen theater program. Participants
will develop skills to create original devised theater in collaboration with a working
theater company in residence at IRT.

New: Wharton Global High School Investment Competition
“The Wharton Global High School Investment Competition is a free, experiential
investment challenge for high school students (9th to 12th grade) and teachers.
Students work in teams of four to seven, guided by a teacher as their advisor, and have
access to an online stock market simulator. Together, they learn about strategy-
building, teamwork, communication, risk, diversification, company and industry
analysis, and many other aspects of investing.”
“The annual Congressional App Challenge is an opportunity for young people to
cultivate their skills in these STEM disciplines and to begin thinking about their
futures in the many American industries that will rely on emerging technologies and
STEM innovation in the coming years. Students may use any programming language
they choose, including C, C++, JavaScript, Python, Ruby, “block code,” etc.
New: The Voice of Democracy Audio-Essay Contest
The Voice of Democracy is a democratic and patriotic-themed essay contest. This
year’s theme is “How Are You Showing Patriotism and Support for Our Country?”
Students will draft an essay that treats the theme with imagination and human interest,
record their reading of it to a CD/flash drive, and submit it to their local VFW post.
Gilder Lehrman Institute: David McCullough Essay Contest
“Students are invited to submit an interpretive essay focusing on close reading and
analysis of one primary source from American history, 1491 to 2001, in the Gilder
Lehrman Collection of more than 87,000 historical documents, or students are invited
to submit a research essay incorporating primary and secondary sources on a topic in
American history from 1491 to 2001. The David McCullough Essay Prizes recognize
fourteen outstanding high school students with prizes of up to $5,000.”

“The TurnUp Civic Tech Challenge welcomes folks under age 26 to share their idea
for a civic technology project that will promote youth voter registration, turnout, or
activism. Enter for the chance to win up to $25,000 and TurnUp's support to help
bring your vision to life. We welcome projects in any phase of execution, whether it's
an idea or already in the works.”

“In order to push toward our goal of making education accessible, Study.com has

“This year, we are inaugurating our first Financial Education PSA Scholarship to
current and incoming undergraduate and graduate students. The goal is to provide
students with an outlet to educate their fellows in an area of financial literacy that
interests them. You will write a public service announcement (PSA) addressed to your
peers. Choose a topic related to financial literacy and craft a persuasive and
informative PSA according to the guidelines below. The winning submission, selected
by our scholarship selection committee, will receive $1,500.”

Whichever extra-curricular program, internship, or community service activity a
student may participate in, they should be sure to ask their supervisor/coordinator to
write a letter of appreciation before it concludes – it is sometimes very difficult to
obtain this later on. And the more personal & detailed the letter, the better. A copy
should then be submitted to your counselor.
